Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Project: Enriching Security Curricula and Enhancing Awareness of Security in Computer Science and Beyond

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is building our nation's capacity to develop a workforce well trained in computer security. Faculty from the University of Houston, University of Houston-Downtown and Texas Southern University, are developing interactive courseware and conducting workshops on the latest machine learning, data mining, natural language processing and statistics techniques as applied to computer security. Courseware on security-critical domains such as wireless sensor networks, and on key societal privacy and security concerns is also being developed. Workshops are being organized to cross-fertilize security curricula with related fields and topics and to develop a broad-based consensus on courseware contents. In addition to interactive courseware for security courses, materials are being developed to infuse security topics and increase awareness of information assurance in the broader computer science curriculum and, beyond computer science, in other STEM disciplines. A hypertextbook integrating the courseware is being implemented.

Through faculty workshops, a community of information assurance education and research scholars is being created. This community will build bridges between information assurance professionals and professionals in related fields. The workshops are training diverse groups of faculty from different types of institutions.

Courseware and other results are available in the National Science Digital Library as well as at a project-specific web site which also links to exemplary courseware developed elsewhere. Courseware and workshops are being rigorously evaluated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to create ``plug-and-play" modules on cutting-edge topics in cyber security and privacy, and to disseminate them broadly through workshops.

We created 14 different ``plug-and-play'' modules, organized around three broad themes, that can be dropped into security and privacy courses, or courses that would benefit from discussion of security and privacy topics. The three themes are: 

  1. Security Analytics: We created five modules in this theme. They are: Data Mining for Security (Duration: 9-12 lecture hours), Machine Learning for Security (9-12 lecture hours), Natural Language Processing for Security(6-9 lecture hours), Privacy Preservation in Data Mining (4.5-6 lecture hours), and Statistics for Security (9-12 lecture hours).
  2. Distributed Systems: We created four modules in this theme. They are: Mobile Security and Privacy (4.5-6 lecture hours), Security and Protocols for Wireless Sensor Networks (6-9 lecture hours), Timing and Implementation Issues in WSNs (4.5-6 lecture hours), and Intrusion Detection (6-9 lecture hours).
  3. Security and Privacy Beyond Computer Science: We created five modules in this theme. They are: Electronic Voting (3-4.5 lecture hours), Internet Crime (3 lecture hours), Digital Content Protection (3-4.5 lecture hours), Inference Control (3 lecture hours), and Privacy Issues in Social Networks (4.5-6 lecture hours). 

These modules were tested, cross-tested and revised with input from students and faculty members who used them.

A new, unique Security Analytics course was created at the University of Houston, which uses three of the modules developed as part of this project. It was approved as a regular graduate course and a version of it was approved as a regular undergraduate course. This course has been taught at the University of Houston four times already to both undergraduate and graduate students. Security Beyond CS modules have become a regular part of INTRD187/188 Freshman Seminar curriculum at University of Massachusetts-Boston, since Spring 2018. The intrusion detection module is used regularly in the intrusion detection course taught at the University of Houston.

Thirteen workshops were organized in total. Four workshops were organized in years one and two to build bridges between the security community and the communities of data analytics, distributed systems and other communities that would benefit from security knowledge. They include: IEEE MWSN 2013 colocated with IEEE SECON 2013, a SIGCSE 2014 Birds-of-a-feather session, a presentation at ACET 2014 and one at ACM CCSC 2014.

Five workshops were organized for bridge building and dissemination of our modules during years three through six of the project. They include: a full-day workshop at University of Houston, Houston Security Day in 2015, and four ACM Annual International Workshop on Security and Privacy Analytics (IWSPA), collocated with ACM CODASPY conferences, with proceedings in the ACM Digital Library. Four additional workshops were organized in year six, one at Texas Southern University and three at University of Houston, for mostly dissemination  of our modules at which faculty and PhD students were exposed to our modules and cutting-edge security topics. Several faculty members and students, who attended these workshops, have expressed interest in using the materials and some have asked for additional materials. Some of these faculty members have reported using the materials also.  

The IWSPA workshops included research on security and privacy analytics with proceedings published in the ACM Digital Library. The papers and abstracts published in these proceedings have been downloaded more than 10,000 times (according to data maintained by ACM) and received over 20 citations so far (according to Google Scholar and ACM data). We also organized two panel discussions: a panel discussion at IEEE MWSN 2013, which recommended a basics of security course, and a panel at ACM IWSPA 2015 on Essential Data Analytics Knowledge for Cyber Security Professionals and Students, which lead to a highly visible paper in IEEE Security and Privacy in December 2015, which alone has been downloaded more than 1,400 times already as of September 2018 as per IEEE Xplore. This paper was in the top 50 downloaded articles list from IEEE Security and Privacy for several months and in the top 25 list for three months. A poster session on the modules was organized at ACM IWSPA 2016 and a tutorial on Security Analytics: Adapting Data Science for Security Challenges at IWSPA 2018.

In addition to the five proceedings in ACM Digital library and IEEE Xplore, 15 peer-reviewed conference/workshop papers and seven peer-reviewed journal papers were published. One of the papers received the Best Paper Award-First Place at the 17th International Conference on Intelligent Text Processing and Computational Linguistics (CICLING 2016).

We created a website to disseminate these modules and videos. The link for the website was advertised in IWSPA proceedings in 2017-18. This website received thousands of hits from all over the world. 

We estimate that more than 700 US faculty and students have been exposed to our modules so far through our efforts.
